comment: nice tree introduction for beginner, thanks!

I resolve the code that you propose, nice!   <Kotlin 1.1> fun findSum(tree: NodeTree): Int {     var currentElement = tree     var right = tree      var countRoot = currentElement.data     if(currentElement.left != null){         currentElement = currentElement.left!!         countRoot += findSum(currentElement)     }      if(right.right != null){         right = right.right!!         countRoot += findSum(right)     }      return countRoot }

- binary tree is a tree with at most 2 nodes - a linked list counts as a tree as it "could have" other nodes - no two references can link to the same node - "root node" is the first node (a node with no parents)
How did he get the O(2n) originally instead of just O(n)? Doesn't it only recurse at most N times?
I made this algorithms with php and worked successfully 😊
nitpick, but I believe that the Node class as shown in 0:43 needs a member that is a pointer to another Node. it's illegal to have a member of the same class.

Thank you.

*Trees nodes have have however many children they want, don't have to be binary. *Trees CANNOT have two or more references to the same node. If you are looking for a specific node, there is one path along specific branches you need to take to get there. In other words, child nodes will never be connected directly below the root.

Hi , thank you for your valuable videos. Actually i have basic knowledge of all the concepts. When i am taking coding questions, i am stuck with representation of  converting problem into coding representation. i can think of my solution. but i start to write code. i am stuck with how we represent the problem as array or make list of some classes with properties like that. can u help me to resolve this.  Please find the problem and i started to solve this problem. where i am making mistakes.      Merging bubbles Alice is playing with bubbles. She is standing at point (0, 0) and has created N bubbles. Each bubble can be characterized by there parameters:  v: denoting the size of the bubble x: denoting the x coordinate of the bubble y: denoting the y coordinate of the bubble The following process will take place as long as there are two or more bubbles left:  Alice will choose the bubble closest to her (in case there are multiple options for a bubble she will choose the largest one among them). (Note: Here distance between two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) is equal to  After choosing the first bubble, similarly, she will choose the second bubble from the bubbles left. Let the two bubbles chosen have parameters as [ v1, x1, y1 ] (first bubble) and [ v2, x2, y2 ] (second bubble) respectively . She will merge the two bubbles chosen and a new bubble with parameters [ v1+v2, x1 - x2, y1 - y2 ] will be formed. You are given array Arr containing the characteristics of the N bubbles.  Task  Determine the coordinates of the last bubble left after the process ends.  Notes  Assume 1-based indexing. There could be multiple bubbles at the same point. Explanation  Assumptions  N = 4 Arr = [ [9,1,0] , [4,9,0] , [12,0,1], [15,4,0] ] Approach  There are two bubbles closest to Alice: [9, 1, 0] and [12, 0, 1] and among these the larger bubble (i.e [12, 0, 1] ) is choosen as the first bubble, So [9, 1, 0] will be choosen as the second bubble. The new bubble formed after merging these two bubbles is [21, -1, 1]. The new array of bubbles will be [ [4, 9, 0] , [15, 4, 0] , [21, -1, 1] ]. Now, the bubbles [21, -1, 1] and [15, 4, 0] will be chosen and the new resulting bubble will be [36, -5, 1]. Finally, bubbles [36, -5, 1] and [4, 9, 0] are chosen and the new bubble formed will be [40, -14, 1]. Now there is only one bubble left at coordinates (-14, 1) and this is the answer. Function description  Complete the function solve provided in the editor. This function takes the following 2 parameters and returns the required answer:  N: Represents the size of array Arr Arr: Represents the elements of array Arr Input format  Note: This is the input format that you must use to provide custom input (available above the Compile and Test button).  The first line contains T denoting the number of test cases. T also specifies the number of times you have to run the solve function on a different set of inputs. For each test case: The first line contains N denoting the size of array Arr. Each of the next N  lines contains 3 space-separated integers. The ith line denotes the characteristics of the ith bubble: [v,x,y]. Output format For each test case in a new line, print the coordinates of the last bubble.  Constraints  1≤T≤10  2≤N≤105  1≤vi≤105  −105≤xi,yi≤105    Sample input 1  2 4 9 1 -0 4 9 0 12 0 1 15 4 0 4 2 1 0 3 -2 -1 5 3 4 Sample output 1  -14 1 -4 -3  Explanation The first line contains the number of test cases, T = 2.  The first test case  The first test case is explained in the problem statement.    The second test case  Given  N = 4 Arr = [ [2, 1, 0], [3, -2, -1], [5, 3, 4], [8, 2, 2] ] Approach  The bubble closest to Alice is [2, 1, 0] and the second closest bubble is [3, -2, -1] , after merging these two bubbles the new bubble formed will be [5, 3, 1]. Now Arr=[ [5, 3, 1], [5, 3, 4] , [8, 2, 2] ] Now, the bubble [8, 2, 2] is chosen as the first bubble and [5, 3, 1] as the second. The new bubble formed after merging these two bubbles will be [13, -1, 1]. Finally, bubbles [13, -1, 1] and [5, 3, 4] are chosen as the first and second bubbles respectively. The new bubble formed after merging these two bubbles will be [18, -4, -3]. The last bubble has coordinates (-4, -3) which is the required answer.  Sample input 2  1 5 2 -4 5 5 3 -2 2 -2 0 2 0 -0 2 -5 2 Sample output 2  8 -5 Sample input 3  1 5 1 -5 3 3 2 -2 4 -1 0 4 5 -1 3 -3 3 Sample output 3  0 -3           My approach   public class MergingBubble { public int FindLastBubble() { var totalNoofTestCases = Convert.ToInt32(Console.ReadLine()); for(int i=0;i<totalNoofTestCases;i++) {     var sizeOfArray = Convert.ToInt32(Console.ReadLine());     List<Parameters> bubblesList = new List<Parameters>();      for(int j=0;j<sizeOfArray;j++)     {         var readBubblePoints =Console.ReadLine();         var SplitPoints = readBubblePoints.split(' ');          var bubbleParameters = new Parameters(SplitPoints[0],SplitPoints[1],SplitPoints[2]);          bubblesList.Add(bubbleParameters);      }      int MinDistance =-1; int x1,x2,y1,y2=0;      for( int k=0;k<bubblesList.Length-1;k++)     {         int distancebtTwoPoints = Math.Sqrt(Math.Square(bubblesList[k].x)-bubblesList[k+1].x) + Math.Square(bubblesList[k].y-bubblesList[k+1].y);          if(MinDistance ==0)         MinDistance =distancebtTwoPoints;         else if( MinDistance > distancebtTwoPoints)          {                MinDistance = distancebtTwoPoints;                x1 = bubblesList[k].x;                x2 = bubblesList[k+1].x;                y1 = bubblesList[k].y;                y2 = bubblesList[k+1].y;          }                          }     } } }  public class Parameters {     public int Value{get;set;}     public int X{get;set;}     public int Y{get;set;}     public bool isFlagged {get;set;}      public Parameters(int v,int x, int y)     {         Value =v;         X=x;         Y=y;     } }

Consider how the tree changes when you add a number to the root. Any number can be added to extend the tree by one. Let's say we add a node at the top with a value of 1, now the summation will run the exact same way, but then tunnel upward one more level to the root value 1. There is one more computation done. Thus O(n) time complexity.  However in other situations, when you add a value to the tree it by design propagates outward. It creates an entire duplicate tree underneath it. An example is the Fibonacci sequence. Adding a value at the top means mirroring the entire tree underneath. This is O(2^n)  Searching a tree that exists is O(n), but an algorithm that builds a tree with # of leafs branching outward from each node in the chain is O(#^n).
